     2â†’  "task_description": "# AI Agent Development Learning Path

Create a structured, progressive learning path that takes developers from AI fundamentals to building production MCP servers with TypeScript. Includes prerequisites, learning objectives, and clear progression between modules.

## Rationale
Addresses the core pain point of 'no clear pathway for learning AI agent development with TypeScript' - the primary reason developers visit this site. A structured path differentiates us from fragmented tutorials elsewhere.

## User Stories
- As a Spanish-speaking developer new to AI, I want a clear learning path so that I know exactly what to study and in what order
- As a developer with some AI experience, I want to identify my current level so that I can skip fundamentals and dive into advanced topics

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Learning path has 5+ modules with clear progression
- [ ] Each module has prerequisites and learning objectives
- [ ] Path includes hands-on projects at each level
- [ ] Visual roadmap shows progression and estimated time
- [ ] Users can bookmark their current position
",
     3â†’  "workflow_type": "feature"
     4â†’}

entries.content:
Now let me analyze this task systematically to determine its complexity and appropriate workflow.

## Analysis

**Task**: Create a structured AI Agent Development Learning Path for a Docusaurus site

**Project Context**: 
- Docusaurus (React-based documentation framework)
- Single service, frontend-focused
- Existing patterns for documentation content

### Scope Analysis
- **Estimated files**: 10-15 files
  - 5+ MDX/markdown files for learning modules
  - 2-3 React components for visual roadmap
  - 2-3 React components for progress tracking/bookmarking
  - 1-2 configuration files (docusaurus.config.js, sidebar)
- **Services**: 1 (main Docusaurus site)
- **Cross-cutting**: No, contained to learning path section

### Integration Analysis
- **External services**: None
- **New dependencies**: Potentially minimal (localStorage for bookmarking, possibly a lightweight state management)
- **Research needed**: No - Docusaurus is well-documented, React patterns are standard

### Infrastructure Analysis
- **Docker changes**: No
- **Database changes**: No (progress tracking via localStorage)
- **Config changes**: Minor (Docusaurus config for new sections)

### Knowledge Analysis
- **Patterns exist**: Yes - Docusaurus documentation patterns are established
- **Research required**: No - standard React + Docusaurus
- **Unfamiliar tech**: None

### Risk Analysis
- **Risk level**: Low
- **Concerns**: Content organization, UX for progress tracking, visual roadmap design
- **No security concerns**: No auth, payments, or sensitive data handling

## Decision: **STANDARD** Complexity

This is a standard feature because:
- 10-15 files (upper range of standard)
- Single service
- No external integrations
- Minimal infrastructure changes
- Existing patterns in codebase
- No unfamiliar technology

It does **NOT** need research because Docusaurus and React are well-documented with existing patterns.

1â†’--- 2â†’sidebar_position: 1 3â†’title: Fundamentos y Core Four 4â†’--- 5â†’ 6â†’# Fundamentos y Core Four: La Arquitectura de Claude Code 7â†’ 8â†’## IntroducciÃ³n: Cuatro Piezas, Un Sistema Composicional 9â†’ 10â†’En 2025, el desarrollo asistido por IA ha evolucionado mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de los simples prompts en una interfaz de chat. Claude Code y herramientas similares ahora ofrecen mÃºltiples mecanismos de extensiÃ³n: **Skills**, **Slash Commands**, **MCP Servers** y **Sub-agents**. Entender cuÃ¡ndo usar cada uno no es solo una cuestiÃ³n de preferencia personal, sino de arquitectura fundamental. 11â†’ 12â†’El error mÃ¡s comÃºn que cometen los desarrolladores al adoptar estas herramientas es tratarlas como alternativas intercambiables. Convertir todos los slash commands en skills, anidar sub-agents innecesariamente, o crear MCPs cuando un simple prompt bastarÃ­a. La realidad es que estas cuatro piezas **no son substitutos**, son **composicionales**: cada una resuelve un problema especÃ­fico y juntas forman un sistema coherente para el desarrollo agentico. 13â†’ 14â†’Esta guÃ­a te ayudarÃ¡ a comprender cuÃ¡ndo usar cada mecanismo, cÃ³mo componen entre sÃ­, y quÃ© patrones de diseÃ±o aplicar para evitar la sobre-ingenierÃ­a. El objetivo no es maximizar el uso de todas las capacidades avanzadas, sino elegir la herramienta correcta para cada trabajo y mantener la arquitectura simple y mantenible. 15â†’ 16â†’## Fundamentos: La Arquitectura de Claude Code 17â†’ 18â†’Antes de comparar Skills, MCP, Sub-agents y Slash Commands, es crucial entender los **Core Four**: los cuatro elementos fundamentales que componen cualquier agente en Claude Code. 19â†’ 20â†’### Los Core Four 21â†’ 22â†’1. **Contexto**: La memoria de trabajo del agente. Incluye CLAUDE.md (instrucciones de proyecto), archivos leÃ­dos, conversaciÃ³n actual, y estado acumulado. 23â†’ 24â†’2. **Modelo**: El LLM subyacente (Claude Opus 4.5, Sonnet 4.5, Haiku 4.5). Determina capacidad de razonamiento, velocidad, y costo. 25â†’ 26â†’3. **Prompt**: La unidad fundamental de instrucciÃ³n. Define quÃ© debe hacer el agente, cÃ³mo debe pensarlo, y quÃ© formato seguir. 27â†’ 28â†’4. **Herramientas**: Las capacidades que el agente puede invocar (Read, Write, Bash, Grep, MCP servers personalizados, etc.). 29â†’ 30â†’```mermaid 31â†’graph TB 32â†’ A["ğŸ“š Contexto
(Memoria de trabajo)"] 33â†’ B["ğŸ§  Modelo
(Claude Opus/Sonnet/Haiku)"] 34â†’ C["ğŸ’¬ Prompt
(InstrucciÃ³n fundamental)"] 35â†’ D["ğŸ”§ Herramientas
(Read, Write, Bash, MCP...)"] 36â†’ 37â†’ E["Agente Coherente"] 38â†’ 39â†’ A --> E 40â†’ B --> E 41â†’ C --> E 42â†’ D --> E 43â†’ 44â†’ style A fill:#0288d1,stroke:#fff,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff 45â†’ style B fill:#7b1fa2,stroke:#fff,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff 46â†’ style C fill:#2e7d32,stroke:#fff,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff 47â†’ style D fill:#e65100,stroke:#fff,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff 48â†’ style E fill:#f57c00,stroke:#fff,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff 49â†’``` 50â†’ 51â†’â˜… Insight â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 52â†’Los Core Four are **elementos independientes** que se combinan para formar un agente funcional. Modificar cualquiera de ellos (cambiar modelo, mejorar prompt, agregar herramientas) afecta el comportamiento total. Las cuatro extensiones que veremos (Skills, Slash Commands, MCP, Sub-agents) son simplemente formas de modificar estos elementos de manera composicional. 53â†’â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 54â†’ 55â†’### El Prompt Sigue Siendo Fundamental 56â†’ 57â†’AquÃ­ estÃ¡ la verdad incÃ³moda que muchos desarrolladores olvidan al emocionarse con Skills y Sub-agents: **el prompt es la unidad fundamental de todo**. No importa cuÃ¡n sofisticada sea tu arquitectura de skills o cuÃ¡ntos MCP servers tengas configurados, todo se reduce a quÃ© le estÃ¡s diciendo al modelo que haga. 58â†’ 59â†’Esto significa: 60â†’ 61â†’- **Empezar con prompts simples**: Antes de crear un skill reutilizable, afina el prompt conversacionalmente. 62â†’- **Prompt engineering primero**: La mayorÃ­a de problemas se resuelven con mejor redacciÃ³n del prompt, no con mÃ¡s abstracciones. 63â†’- **No entregar control prematuramente**: Subir a skills o sub-agents muy rÃ¡pido puede oscurecer el reasoning crÃ­tico. 64â†’ 65â†’### CÃ³mo Se Componen Estas Piezas 66â†’ 67â†’Los cuatro mecanismos (Skills, Slash Commands, MCP, Sub-agents) son formas de **modificar o extender los Core Four**: 68â†’ 69â†’- **Skills** modifican el contexto y el prompt automÃ¡ticamente cuando el modelo detecta relevancia 70â†’- **Slash Commands** invocan prompts predefinidos manualmente con argumentos opcionales 71â†’- **MCP Servers** extienden las herramientas disponibles para conectar sistemas externos 72â†’- **Sub-agents** crean instancias separadas con su propio contexto, modelo, prompt y herramientas 73â†’ 74â†’La clave del diseÃ±o arquitectÃ³nico efectivo es entender quÃ© estÃ¡s modificando y por quÃ©. 75â†’ 76â†’```mermaid 77â†’graph TB 78â†’ subgraph CoreFour["Core Four Fundamental"] 79â†’ CTX["ğŸ“š Contexto"] 80â†’ MODEL["ğŸ§  Modelo"] 81â†’ PROMPT["ğŸ’¬ Prompt"] 82â†’ TOOLS["ğŸ”§ Herramientas"] 83â†’ end 84â†’ 85â†’ subgraph Extensiones["Cuatro Mecanismos de ExtensiÃ³n"] 86â†’ SKILL["âš¡ Skills
(Contexto + Prompt)"] 87â†’ SLASH["âŒ¨ï¸ Slash Commands
(Prompt + Manual)"] 88â†’ MCP["ğŸ”Œ MCP Servers
(Herramientas)"] 89â†’ SUBAGENT["ğŸ¤– Sub-agents
(Todos separados)"] 90â†’ end 91â†’ 92â†’ CTX -.->|modifica| SKILL 93â†’ PROMPT -.->|modifica| SKILL 94â†’ 95â†’ PROMPT -.->|invoca| SLASH 96â†’ 97â†’ TOOLS -.->|extiende| MCP 98â†’ 99â†’ CTX -.->|aislado| SUBAGENT 100â†’ MODEL -.->|aislado| SUBAGENT 101â†’ PROMPT -.->|aislado| SUBAGENT 102â†’ TOOLS -.->|aislado| SUBAGENT 103â†’ 104â†’ style CoreFour fill:#37474f,stroke:#fff,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff 105â†’ style Extensiones fill:#455a64,stroke:#fff,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff 106â†’ style SKILL fill:#2e7d32,stroke:#fff,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff 107â†’ style SLASH fill:#1976d2,stroke:#fff,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff 108â†’ style MCP fill:#9c27b0,stroke:#fff,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff 109â†’ style SUBAGENT fill:#f57c00,stroke:#fff,stroke-width:2px,color:#fff 110â†’``` 111â†’ 112â†’â˜… Insight â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 113â†’Cada mecanismo de extensiÃ³n **modifica un subconjunto diferente** de los Core Four. Un skill modifica contexto y prompt (automÃ¡ticamente), un slash command solo invoca un prompt (manualmente), MCP extiende herramientas, y los sub-agents crean una **copia completamente aislada** de todos los elementos. Esto es la razÃ³n por la cual no son intercambiables - cada uno resuelve un problema diferente. 114â†’â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ 115â†’ 116â†’--- 117â†’ 118â†’**Siguiente paso:** [Comparativa y DecisiÃ³n: CuÃ¡ndo usar cada mecanismo](./02-comparativa-y-decision.md) 119â†’ 120â†’ Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.

1â†’# Specification: AI Agent Development Learning Path 2â†’ 3â†’## Overview 4â†’ 5â†’Build a comprehensive, structured learning path for the CÃ³digo Sin Siesta Docusaurus site that guides Spanish-speaking developers from AI fundamentals to building production-ready MCP servers with TypeScript. This feature creates an interactive roadmap with progress tracking, addressing the core pain point that there is no clear pathway for learning AI agent development with TypeScript in Spanish. 6â†’ 7â†’## Workflow Type 8â†’ 9â†’**Type**: feature 10â†’ 11â†’**Rationale**: This is new functionality being added to an existing Docusaurus site. We're creating new content pages, navigation structure, interactive UI components (visual roadmap, bookmark system), and enhancing the existing documentation architecture. This is not a refactoring of existing code or a simple content update - it's a comprehensive feature implementation that includes content architecture, UI development, and state management. 12â†’ 13â†’## Task Scope 14â†’ 15â†’### Services Involved 16â†’- **main** (primary) - Docusaurus React/JavaScript frontend serving Spanish documentation 17â†’ 18â†’### This Task Will: 19â†’- [ ] Create a structured learning path with 6 progressive modules (Fundamentos â†’ TypeScript â†’ IA BÃ¡sica â†’ Agentes â†’ MCP â†’ ProducciÃ³n) 20â†’- [ ] Build a visual roadmap component showing progression flow with time estimates 21â†’- [ ] Implement bookmark/progress tracking functionality using localStorage 22â†’- [ ] Integrate the learning path into the existing sidebar navigation 23â†’- [ ] Add hands-on projects and exercises for each module 24â†’- [ ] Define clear prerequisites and learning objectives per module 25â†’- [ ] Support multiple entry points for developers at different skill levels 26â†’ 27â†’### Out of Scope: 28â†’- Authentication-based progress tracking (using localStorage only) 29â†’- Backend API for progress persistence 30â†’- Multi-language i18n (Spanish only for this iteration) 31â†’- Content Management System integration 32â†’- Automated progress validation/quizzes 33â†’- Certificate generation 34â†’ 35â†’## Service Context 36â†’ 37â†’### main 38â†’ 39â†’**Tech Stack:** 40â†’- Language: JavaScript 41â†’- Framework: React + Docusaurus 3.x 42â†’- Component Pattern: Functional React components with hooks 43â†’- Styling: CSS Modules 44â†’- Diagram Support: Mermaid diagrams (already configured) 45â†’- i18n: Spanish ('es' locale configured) 46â†’ 47â†’**Entry Point:** `docusaurus.config.js` 48â†’ 49â†’**How to Run:** 50â†’```bash 51â†’npm run start 52â†’``` 53â†’ 54â†’**Port:** 3000 55â†’ 56â†’**Key Directories:** 57â†’- `docs/` - Markdown/MDX content organized by category 58â†’- `src/components/` - React components 59â†’- `src/css/` - Global and module CSS 60â†’- `sidebars.js` - Navigation structure configuration 61â†’ 62â†’**Existing Patterns:** 63â†’- Content organized in nested folders (e.g., `docs/proyectos/taller-ia-agentes-mcp/`) 64â†’- Frontmatter with `sidebar_position` and `title` 65â†’- Mermaid diagrams for visual explanations 66â†’- Table-based content organization 67â†’- Learning path structures with durations and prerequisites (see `guia-composicion/`) 68â†’ 69â†’## Files to Modify 70â†’ 71â†’| File | Service | What to Change | 72â†’|------|---------|---------------| 73â†’| `sidebars.js` | main | Add new category "Ruta de Aprendizaje IA Agents" with 6 module entries | 74â†’| `docusaurus.config.js` | main | Add navbar item for learning path (optional, if we want top-level nav) | 75â†’ 76â†’## Files to Reference 77â†’ 78â†’These files show patterns to follow: 79â†’ 80â†’| File | Pattern to Copy | 81â†’|------|----------------| 82â†’| `docs/proyectos/taller-ia-agentes-mcp/intro.md` | Learning path introduction structure with rutas (rÃ¡pida, completa, empresarial), prerequisites, module table with durations | 83â†’| `docs/arquitectura-ia/guia-composicion/01-fundamentos-core-four.md` | Module content      3â†’  "description": "# AI Agent Development Learning Path

Create a structured, progressive learning path that takes developers from AI fundamentals to building production MCP servers with TypeScript. Includes prerequisites, learning objectives, and clear progression between modules.

## Rationale
Addresses the core pain point of 'no clear pathway for learning AI agent development with TypeScript' - the primary reason developers visit this site. A structured path differentiates us from fragmented tutorials elsewhere.

## User Stories
- As a Spanish-speaking developer new to AI, I want a clear learning path so that I know exactly what to study and in what order
- As a developer with some AI experience, I want to identify my current level so that I can skip fundamentals and dive into advanced topics

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Learning path has 5+ modules with clear progression
- [ ] Each module has prerequisites and learning objectives
- [ ] Path includes hands-on projects at each level
- [ ] Visual roadmap shows progression and estimated time
- [ ] Users can bookmark their current position
",
